review: Tom Cruise—Energizer Bunny of actioners—will miss the adrenaline junkie 'Mission: Impossible' stunts; if he has a say, 'The Final Reckoning' may not be final.

If this is truly the end for the icon as Ethan Hunt, it could’ve been worse, but a cleaner story with a shorter runtime could’ve elevated the incredible stunt sequences rather than relying on them to shoulder the weight of the film.

In the pantheon of Mission: Impossible movies, I don't think Final Reckoning quite tops Fallout, with Henry Cavill as the villain and that helicopter finale. While Ghost Protocol, with the legendary Burj Khalifa sequence, might be the people's champion.

reviewer:
Lindsey Bahr
Associated Press
TOP CRITIC
review: It’s hard to shake the feeling that in attempting to tie everything together, “Mission: Impossible” lost the plot.

reviewer:
Joe Botten
Loud and Clear Reviews
review: Lilo & Stitch emerges as a surprising beacon of authenticity because it remembers why it mattered so much in the first place.

reviewer:
Olly Richards
Time Out
TOP CRITIC
review: It’s a sweet, funny, simple story with a cute central duo and modest scale (thanks to a smaller than typical budget). It turns out to be an excellent candidate for a do-over, able to establish a personality of its own without the original looming over it.

...Camp supplies this Hawaiian story with a surprising realism. He doesn't rely on the formula based on the 2002 film in order to constantly please, but, with a style reminiscent of independent cinema...[Full review in Spanish]
This adaptation complements and deepens the story in a way that few, if any, Disney remakes have before, making for a heartfelt, funny, and enjoyable ride for kids and adults alike.

Lilo & Stitch is a version of the animated original that simply exists, and nothing else. It does what it says on the tin, for better or worse, and leaves your mind as soon as it ends, with no other function than to generate its studio a ton of money.
Director Dean Fleischer Camp laces this edition with such heart, humour, and respect for its Hawaiian culture, that you’d be hard pressed not to be swept up in its harmless charm.

reviewer:
Charles Koplinski
Reel Talk with Chuck and Pam
review: While so many films examine the toxicity that can develop in male friendships, DeYoung is more interested in the insecurities that fuel them.
It’s the funniest feel-bad comedy of the year.

reviewer:
Meredith G. White
Arizona Republic
TOP CRITIC
review: What it lacks in originality, it makes up for in that the actors feel rooted in reality.
It’s a light but often thoughtful and touching film that eventually leans into romance, while avoiding the usual sentimental clichés.

Laura Piani paints a vivid film with a lush palette, but, ultimately, the story of her protagonist's life is the most lackluster part of the movie, relying on typical tropes rather than reinventing the romance genre as Austen so often did

reviewer:
Lindsey Bahr
Associated Press
TOP CRITIC
review: It may not be a strict adaptation, but it has Jane Austen’s soul.

reviewer:
Lily Janiak
San Francisco Chronicle
TOP CRITIC
review: The result, with Agathe neither towering wit nor dumpster fire nor book snob, is a refreshingly light touch and a heroine unexaggerated by what Hollywood always thinks we want.

Jane Austen Wrecked My Life knows its audience and caters directly to them. If you, like the film’s protagonist, are obsessed with Jane Austen literature and film adaptations, you’ll certainly adore this love letter to the great author.

reviewer:
Charles Koplinski
Reel Talk with Chuck and Pam
review: All of this is fine, yet it’s not enough to overlook the heavy-handed approach regarding the film’s theme.
To stand out, the only possible way forward [for The Last Rodeo] should have been to establish these characters and their motifs well. Sadly, director Avnet fails to do exactly that.
A better role for McDonough than other things we’ve seen him do, confirming the maxim that more actors should write roles for themselves.

Given the plethora of holes in the plot, I was certain the ending would follow suit or be far too pat and predictable, but I’m happy to report I was wrong. As it turns out, the ending is the best part of the entire movie, but it’s too little too late.

[The Last Rodeo] manages to paint a vivid portrait of the residents of Tulsa, men of few words, identified by their cowboy hats and wrangler pants, whose loyalty to their loved ones drives them to overcome any obstacle. [Full review in Spanish]
Both actors bring a natural feel to their characters that will make audiences feel for them both. The plot is over the top and gets more wild as things progress.

A movie that's unafraid to take risks and lets its leads shine in a glaring spotlight, The Surrender occasionally falters in its pacing, but ultimately delivers a fraught family drama replete with gag-inducing body horror and a whole lot of blood.

reviewer:
Richard Whittaker
Austin Chronicle
TOP CRITIC
review: Underneath the savage occult aspects of the story remains a constant exploration of what it means to see your loved ones as flawed, rounded humans, and ultimately as mortal.
Rereleased by StudioCanal to celebrate Shakespeare’s 400th anniversary, his breathtaking adaptation of King Lear proves, so far at least, to be as immune to the effects of time as the original

reviewer:
Mike Massie
Gone With The Twins
review: An arresting amalgamation of unforgettable imagery.

Gorgeously shot and intellectually/emotionally provoking, the film tantalizes with transcendent revelations but is simultaneously unbalanced in how it approaches its characters and minimalist storytelling.

reviewer:
Sebastian Zavala Kahn
Loud and Clear Reviews
review: Warwick Thornton’s The New Boy is not a movie interested in telling a conventional narrative, but in building tone and developing themes through potent imagery and interesting characterisation.
There is an exceptional theme at the heart of The New Boy that is certainly touched upon, in often profound ways, but it isn’t explored as deeply as it absolutely could have been.

There is no right way to interpret this film, and maybe that is what makes it so wonderful. The New Boy will open your mind and your heart, as you’re taken on a spiritual journey of an orphan and a nun navigating their beliefs.

reviewer:
Roger Ebert
Chicago Sun-Times
TOP CRITIC
review: The filmmakers, John Hanson and Rob Nilsson, use the documentary springboard of Martinson's memories to move into a film that also looks like a documentary.
The Wiz's retelling of The Wizard of Oz is certainly ambitious, but the game performances of its star-studded cast are let down by lifeless direction.

reviewer:
KT Mahe
For Your Reference Podcast
review: The reimagining of The Wiz positions itself as a classic in its own right. Emotion holds through memorable set pieces and legendary performances.
…it’s the dirty-glitter staging, not the show that’s the problem, not helped by Lumet shooting all the musical sequences from such an extreme distance that we can rarely see the cast’s faces…
It's easy to see why director Sidney Lumet's clunker ranks as one of the most expensive movie flops of all time.
The Wiz can't quite get it together. Nonetheless, this trip up the yellow-brick road has something to please almost everyone.
Despite its marvelous personnel and terrific premise, The Wiz is a bungled mess.
After 35 years, there's nothing more comforting or moving than returning to one of Studio Ghibli's most enduring coming-of-age narratives.

Kiki’s Delivery Service is an entertaining watch with stunning visuals and one important message for everyone to stay true to their core selves, gain independence early on, try new things and explore.

Kiki’s Delivery Service might appear to be “kid’s stuff,” something adults could never sink their teeth into or reflect upon as serious cinema—such a misreading disappears after one screening of Miyazaki’s observant, sensitive film.
Enjoyable.

One of Miyazaki's most fanciful stories, Kiki's Delivery Service may seem on the surface to be just another simple, heartwarming fantasy tale, but it has some serious undertones that can't be easily dismissed.

reviewer:
Brian Bisesi
Horror Movie Club Podcast
review: Final Destination Bloodlines takes itself seriously while simultaneously embracing its ridiculousness. The film does not forget to go big, especially in its jaw-dropping opening scene.

Bloodlines is a respectful resurrection of a series that nurtured the careers of several young directors and filled cinemas for a decade with happy teens who got exactly what they were hoping to see. I reckon we should welcome its return.
The gruesome deaths are loads of fun and ramp up perfectly in terms of tension and scale. Bloodlines is right up there with the best in this series.
Time away from movie screens has done Final Destination a world of good, since this is easily the most enjoyable and accomplished sequel yet.
The dorm-room philosophy of the 25-year-old series is still pondering how wild it is that we all die, how fragile our meatbag bodies are. Now with gory dismemberments and squishy impalements in IMAX!
The prologue rocks, but otherwise, this initially HBO Max-intended sequel looks and feels streaming-small. At least it doesn’t rely on nostalgia and callbacks.

...this new installment not only recovers the essence of inevitable death but also expands the universe with a more mature approach, doses of dark humor, and a reflection on trauma and family heritage. [Full review in Spanish]

It’s often gorgeous to look at, even hypnotic. And yet, for all its visual brilliance and Shults’ often masterful direction, Hurry Up Tomorrow ultimately buckles under the weight of its own self-importance.

Tesfaye is very charismatic and can act; unfortunately, he doesn’t get to showcase his skills in the plotless story written by the musician with Shults and Reza Fahim. It works better as a visual album than a narrative film.

reviewer:
Gavia Baker-Whitelaw
Empire Magazine
TOP CRITIC
review: Despite some impressive woozy visuals and a soundtrack of chart-topping music, there’s not much to recommend this derivative pop-star drama.

reviewer:
Michael O'Sullivan
Washington Post
TOP CRITIC
review: Even some die-hard fans may find themselves wishing for a literal interpretation of the title, because “Hurry Up Tomorrow” can’t end soon enough.

I can’t help but wonder if there might have been a fun B-movie thriller to be found somewhere deep in Hurry Up Tomorrow’s DNA...But that would have required a less pretentious approach...and a more seasoned lead actor.
Deaf President Now! is a rousing, beautifully told chronicle of an example of swift action resulting in lightning-fast change.

reviewer:
Michael O'Sullivan
Washington Post
TOP CRITIC
review: It’s a manifestation of what change makers all too often run into: ears that are metaphorically deaf to the obvious.

reviewer:
Matt Zoller Seitz
RogerEbert.com
TOP CRITIC
review: It’s a stealthy formal triumph that refines existing cinematic language and adds brand new words and phrases to the vocabulary, as it were, because that’s what was needed to do justice to its subject matter.
Deaf President Now! is never redundant and always urgent. It'll surely make your heart explode in happiness.

The film jumps through genres but never settles on a place that asks us to define it. Instead it offers Raptika Apke an absolute showcase to comically show her disgust for her situation and those around it which is all we need to follow her anywhere.
There are laughs aplenty, even as “Sister Midnight” begins to lose creative steam, with the wheels falling off, and the further it falls into the repetitive macabre.

Sister Midnight is wonderful, transfixing in its celluloid-shot cinematography, which makes its many urban-nightscape scenes particularly vibrant in their long shadows, and wonderfully acted by Apte, whose near-feral aggrievement is oddly winning.

reviewer:
Jared Mobarak
Hey, Have You Seen ...?
review: The back half unfolds at a fast pace—perhaps too fast. I think that's kind of the point as Kandhari is all about idiosyncratic juxtapositions with his soundtrack choices, use of animation, and dry humor in traditionally dark, dramatic scenarios.
There are so many grace notes that they almost form a chorus.

reviewer:
Rich Cline
Shadows on the Wall
review: Actor-filmmaker Max Talisman fills the screen with bright colours and sharply well-written dialog that's delivered in an enjoyably off-the-cuff way.
A convincing coming-of-age drama that becomes a less convincing crime drama in the third act. But the largely unknown cast carries this idiosyncratic vision.
With an outstanding lead performance, good character work and a strong message, Bound is a great indie gem that despite becoming a little clunky in its third act, is impressive nonetheless.

reviewer:
Surya Komal
Just for Movie Freaks
review: Bound is a bold exploration of trauma, survival, and redemption, driven by powerful performances and a gripping storyline—at least for the majority of its runtime.
It’s a game, plucky performance by Sadeghian that anchors the film, while the edgy slide guitar score by Ethan Startzman goes far to help ratchet up the tension.
Even when Bound intermittently soars and lands on an emotion that rattles one’s core, it plummets right back into shallow waters, embracing an ethos that is painfully skin-deep.

Bound is definitely a film worth checking out, with first-rate performances from top to bottom and an engaging and emotionally powerful story. Not always an easy watch with its hard-hitting themes, but the film has so much sincerity.

reviewer:
Bill Newcott
The Saturday Evening Post
review: A handsome-looking effort with appealing performances by a cast that seems ready, at any moment, to break the fourth wall and apologize profusely.
Stevan Mena's The Ruse may have a few fun twists in its climax, but the lead up is an overlong, poorly performed mess of clichés and red herrings.
It's not a great sign when a movie needs to devote about ten minutes to a character bluntly explaining everything that has happened ... in its story.

With the title The Ruse, at least writer/director Stevan Mena has done the courtesy of letting viewers know there is little to trust here and that there is a high probability that the story will be absurd and implausible
What could have been a tidy little horror/thriller struggles for air with a surplus of exposition and explanation. Usually the best way to scare is to withhold.

The film spends so much time tying itself up in knots with potential storylines and dramatic tangents that by the time it reaches its dizzying conclusion, it offers up only a frustratingly long yet dull explanation.
Right and wrong are blurry concepts here. What might mean justice for an individual could be devastating to the community.

While the film is beautifully shot...with fog rolling over the river and sunlight streaking through a canopy of branches, the narrative is heavy on witch-hunt tropes and offers little originality, its characters never developed much beyond archetypes.
The Severed Sun is not one of the strongest horror movies of the year so far, but I had an absolute blast watching Dean Puckett's feature debut.
It's a shame the whole thing doesn't add up to much on a narrative or thematic level.
The Severed Sun is a handsomely produced, eerily directed film. The cast shines from the beginning to the end, with each actor delivering a natural, believable performance.

reviewer:
Joshua Stevens
Loud and Clear Reviews
review: Borrowing from recent folk horrors like The Witch and Midsommar, The Severed Sun establishes itself as a worthy entry in the genre.

The Severed Sun is a story of awakening. The horror is psychological as much as supernatural. This is a film about control; who has it, how they keep it, and what it takes to break free. The Severed Sun is a gripping horror, you must watch it!

reviewer:
Sebastian Zavala Kahn
Me gusta el cine
review: It's too obtuse, cryptic, and slow-paced. However, if you're looking for a film that speaks volumes about the role of religion in isolated communities and for vulnerable female populations, you'll surely enjoy "The Severed Sun." [Full review in Spanish].
A witch trial brought to life, The Severed Sun has plenty of fine ideas, but ultimately lacks that magical quality to make it a future classic.
Beyond the general sloppiness in tonal shifts, effects and filmmaking, a film about the terror threat of feral dogs should produce attacks that result in more than just minor redness and irritation.
This is an ugly-looking, repetitive, and dull dead end of whatever it is the movie is trying to be.
The Furst Brothers' A Breed Apart certainly goes for intentional comedy, but is also full of moments that are so terrible they're hysterical.
Directors Griff and Nathan Furst are so inept they make Sharknado director Anthony C. Ferrante look like Paul Thomas Anderson in comparison.
Unless you really hate puppies, I’m not sure what enjoyment you’ll salvage from A Breed Apart.

reviewer:
Branyan Towe
Loud and Clear Reviews
review: A Breed Apart is a bottom of the barrel affair all the way around, despite Grace Caroline Currey, Virginia Gardner, and Page Kennedy giving solid acting efforts. This horror film seems so desperate to be a cult classic without bringing much to the table.
A Breed Apart is a ferociously fun time at the movies.
[T]his is a barely competent and, at times, outright inept bit of storytelling and filmmaking.

If there was any hidden intention to recover something of the spirit of Steven Spielberg's family films from elsewhere, the entire purpose of bringing it to life falls by the wayside. [Full review in Spanish]

reviewer:
Sebastian Zavala Kahn
Me gusta el cine
review: A lethargic final product, with a dense and dark atmosphere, filled with performances lacking in energy or charisma. This is the kind of film that should thrill, but unfortunately, will leave you sedated or at least a bit sleepy. [Full review in Spanish].

While its main plot isn't radically innovative, its subtextual richness and nuanced approach to the complexities of a dysfunctional family from the protagonist's perspective...make it a highly enjoyable experience... [Full review in Spanish]
...it's a classic story in its structure and in a form that, while not original, manages to shed the most common points of major studio productions. [Full review in Spanish]
This misguided take on a dark comedy ultimately lacks laughs, thrills, and overall reverence for severe topics.

reviewer:
Michael Medved
The Michael Medved Show
review: Elegant and stylish ...Indira Varma makes a deep impression as the clearly troubled Jessica, even though for most of this film's very brisk running time, she's not actually alive.
Like any sure-handed cinematic riddle, Matt Winn keeps pushing the teeter-totter at the right times, dropping question marks all the way until the end.

reviewer:
Daniel M. Kimmel
North Shore Movies
review: “The Trouble With Jessica” is less about the dead body than about the problems of the other characters, and how far they’re willing to go to get out of an increasingly messy situation.
Literate and deadpan, this wildly funny black comedy of ethics is a monumental adrenalin rush that will make you squirm and crave a clafouti.

The best black comedies require the courage of their conviction, a need to push the premises to their logical conclusion. Absent any such logic, The Trouble with Jessica finds a conclusion that is worse than illogical. It is safe.

The Trouble with Jessica is a bitingly satirical, well-acted black comedy that runs out of steam after milking its clever premise dry. Director/co-writer Matt Winn packs a wallop in the film's taut and meticulously executed first act.

...reveals the tawdry, untold story about for-profit nursing homes in Canada. This is a movie that everyone should see if they are considering going into a nursing home or committing a relative to one.

Profiles passion and anger of Canadian litigator Melissa Miller as she puts in long hours on class actions (called there “mass torts”) for systemic change and distraught family law suits against for-profit nursing homes/long term care facility chains.

reviewer:
Bill Newcott
The Saturday Evening Post
review: Marin pauses by a parked motorcycle. “Is this Dave’s bike?” he asks. If you need that joke explained to you, then you might not be the target audience for Cheech & Chong’s Last Movie.
Garland successfully continues his mission to challenge audiences to grasp the humanity within a conflict, even among viewers whose politics may not agree.
It's really a nice tribute to... those soldiers.

reviewer:
Sean P. Means
The Movie Cricket
review: Writer-directors Ray Mendoza and Alex Garland … create moments of chaos, blood and pain that are as close as I or any other civilian likely will want to be to the fight.
Ray Mendoza and Alex Garland's stripped-down war movie is solely about the visual and sound aura.
Shocking and urgent, Warfare may be one of the most affecting films you’ll see this year.

Black Bag features slick direction, impressive costume & production design, and a remarkably talented ensemble, but unfortunately it's held back just a little too much by David Koepp's slow-burning screenplay.

... eschewing action sequences and gadgets for mind games, the success and failure of the film comes down to the performances and there are several remarkable ones, each one pulling the audience deeper into the intrigue until the only way out is through.
Micro-aggressions, overt confrontations, cynical exchanges, and provocative mind games abound, all delivered with the right mix of irresistible glamour and disdainful coldness.

reviewer:
Sean P. Means
The Movie Cricket
review: Soderbergh brings a coiled tension to the action and verbal gymnastics of “Black Bag.” … The best part is that Soderbergh does this all so seamlessly that a viewer can admire the technique while not losing the thread of the narrative.

This black bag might not fetch a “House of Mouwad” price point, but “Marc Jacobs” is nothing to sneeze at. Holding some jewels, snacks, and a few keys, this black bag is worth carrying—and surely worth peeking inside. Mysterious, complicated, and vicious.

reviewer:
James Kendrick
Q Network Film Desk
review: While it offers lots of visual wows and shout-outs to those in the know, the movie really works because of the absurd macho competitiveness-turned-bromance between Jack Black and Jason Momoa.
...a bona fide failure that could only appeal to either hardcore fans of the source material or very young, very undiscriminating children.

reviewer:
Keith Phipps
The Reveal (Substack)
TOP CRITIC
review: [A] serviceable-enough reimagining of the classic film. Webb moves the action along.

Rachel Zegler's voice is one of the best of any artist right now and her portrayal as Snow White is captivating, and as much as Gal Gadot physically looked the part of the Evil Queen, her performance was too messy and took me out of the film.
Rachel Zegler is the best part of the live-action remake. Gal Gadot is a bit stiff, and the songs are hit-and-miss. The movie looks spectacular and is best suited for families with young kids.
Somewhere between the animated version and the true life version the Disney magic was lost.

'Drop' never goes so far as to follow the common B movie trope of cheesy-for-the-sake-of-cheesy, although the big final sequence could have benefitted greatly from an extra helping from the fromagerie.

reviewer:
Sean P. Means
The Movie Cricket
review: Landon embraces the inherent tension of creating a thriller all set in the confined space of the restaurant. … Unfortunately, Landon can’t sustain that constricted feeling for the whole run, and the action kind of goes off the rails [near the end].
Pulse-pounding fun with style and the right amount of silly.

reviewer:
KT Mahe
For Your Reference Podcast
review: Drop is a playful contrast on the trope of women in horror by taking charge and having fun with it. An end to end intense thriller.
A first date gone completely off the rails, dripping with tension, tech paranoia, and a whole lot of very entertaining nonsense.
A fun premise gets bogged down by a generic, weak second half. [Full review in Spanish]
Drop has a dastardly clever premise that the cast pulls off superbly making this a thriller well worth checking out.
‘Drop’ is a good time at the movies, a fast-paced thriller with talented leads, an intriguing story, and sleek cinematography.
The entire cast is terrific, especially the two leads. And after this film and Heretic, I’m ready to be the president of the Sophie Thatcher Fan Club.
First-time feature filmmaker Drew Hancock has assembled a terrific cast, providing an engaging science fiction backdrop that tackles real-world issues with a devious twist.

Despite Thatcher’s committed performance and the film’s fluctuating emotional beats, Companion remains a shaky, average effort devoid of real suspense—an interesting idea bogged down by a literal-minded, mechanical, and somewhat draggy execution.
What on the surface looks as if it could be yet another horror yarn off the Blumhouse assembly line is instead a cleverly scripted and zestfully performed fantasy-thriller.

... it never stops pushing its thematic aspects or forgets where the heart lies, so the absurd functions as a delivery mechanism for entertainment and as an exploration of toxic relationships and the strength required to break free.

reviewer:
Sean P. Means
The Movie Cricket
review: Quaid is the son of stars Dennis Quaid and Meg Ryan, and it’s apparent that charisma is an inherited trait. He’s a pleasure to watch, and brings a lightness to a role that could get weirdly heavy.

Novocaine is a fun, exciting, and boisterously bloody time at the movies that takes its novel concept, runs with it with cartoonish glee, and is led by a charming pairing in Jack Quaid and Amber Midthunder. Recommended.

Like Nathan himself, Novocaine takes modest resources and creates something unexpected. While unlikely to revolutionise the action genre, it’s a testament to how much can be done with the right lead and inventive storytelling.
Quaid has a killer grin as well as light comic timing, although you hope he goes on to better things.

reviewer:
Kevin Carr
Fat Guys at the Movies
review: What this movie does well is the fight sequences where Statham dispenses justice. At those moments, it’s exciting, visceral, and thrilling. What this movie doesn’t do well is… everything else.
I'm always down for a Jason Statham action flick and as much as I wanted to love this one, it's not as strong as THE BEEKEEPER and moved much slower than his previous films.
Its a Jason Statham movie and for many that alone is enough.

While Statham's undeniably watchable presence offer some momentary thrills, the film's reliance on an over-the-top and convoluted plot and its disastrously weak villains ultimately transform it into a ridiculous, and unfortunately forgettable watch.
“A Working Man” pulls together better than the usual snatch-and-grab-for-ransom films.

Masterfully shot and directed, with a standout performances from Adrien Brody and Guy Pearce. Some of the themes and a chunk of the writing didn’t work for me, but the commentary on the failed American Dream is solid
The Brutalist is a stunner. A dream for cinephiles everywhere but this is the Holy Grail for film scholars: an instant, definitive entry into film canon.

The drama features notable performances from Brody and Jones, but, despite its visual aesthetics, I have a sneaking suspicion that Corbet ends up demolishing the narrative like a building under construction. [Full review in Spanish]
Brady Corbet's monumental, yet intimately told architectural epic explores the dark side of the American Dream.
The Brutalist is a long and portentous film that loses its way a bit in the second half but still manages to leave you in awe as you watch it unfold.

reviewer:
Desmond Ryan
Philadelphia Inquirer
TOP CRITIC
review: Final Destination is as full of terrible acting as it is devoid of suspense.

reviewer:
Jami Bernard
New York Daily News
TOP CRITIC
review: Not likely to be showing on any in-flight screen soon is "Final Destination," a mediocre fright-fest.
Halfway through the film, you'll find yourself wishing Death would simply hurry up and do its job.
With Rube Goldberg hijinks, the mixture of comedy, shocking kills, and emerging talent helped Final Destination become a classic of 2000s horror.
Director Justin Kurzel mostly avoids comparison to current events — concentrating on the dissonance of violence among the serene surroundings — but the parallels are unavoidable nonetheless.
Jude Law and Nicholas Hoult deliver fantastic performances in The Order, a film that simultaneously breaks our hearts and fills it with terror over and over again.
A thriller about the steps in crime and police movements that radiates solidity and strength, with which Jude Law and Nicholas Hoult have a lot to do with. [Full review in Spanish]
The Order s a tense thriller, with a solid cast and a pace that keeps the viewer's interest. [Full review in Spanish]

reviewer:
Wenlei Ma
The Nightly (AU)
TOP CRITIC
review: The Order doesn’t deploy any fancy tricks or ingenious twists, in some ways, it’s an old-fashioned throwback. That’s what makes it such a satisfying film. It is exactly what it says it is, and it does it with class and discipline.

reviewer:
Laura Venning
Empire Magazine
TOP CRITIC
review: The Order is as tense and visceral as it is timely.
The film doesn’t work without Law, who’s nearly unrecognizable as the disheveled, on-the-edge sort – his usual British charm and disarming accent are nowhere to be found.
The Ballad of Wallis Island is a heartfelt comedy about loss, loneliness, and moving on. [Full review in Spanish]
What sets 'The Ballad of Wallis Island' apart is its refusal to tie up every dangling plot thread in a neat little bow.

reviewer:
Philip De Semlyen
Time Out
TOP CRITIC
review: A bracing, windswept delight.

reviewer:
Sean P. Means
The Movie Cricket
review: The droll chemistry between Basden and Key in their frequent scenes together suggests a comedic collaboration on the order of Fry & Laurie.
This is an absolutely lovely, lovely film.

It makes cosmic sense that the same stretch of time that produced the grotesque post-election quote “Your body, my choice” would also yield a movie that too often (if inadvertently) encapsulates said message.
Nicole Kidman and Harris Dickinson's sexy playtime in Babygirl seems to want to delve deeper into the characters' psyches, but it only does so at the surface level and gets boring.
... exploring the notions of legacy (the road traveled and the road yet to be paved) in a narrative that’s nowhere near as thrilling as it wants to be yet is no less thoughtful.
A hugely boring and unengaging superhero movie with its second-rate patriotic characters. [Full review in Spanish]

It tries a little too hard to get things moving in the first act, and it does feel fairly slight overall, a Minor Marvel. But for the majority of its running time, it soars, largely thanks to Anthony Mackie's potent presence.
Oh Mickey, you’re so fine … just not as fine as most previous pics from Bong Joon Ho.

With its extraordinary premise, one would expect great exaggerations in order to find its hilarity amid the absurd, yet, once more, Bong has created a tale that not only works on multiple levels, it reminds us that life has the meaning we ascribe to it.
There are indeed a lot of intriguing ideas in here, it's just a shame that none of them get their due in a film that's rather inspired, but ultimately overstuffed.

reviewer:
Sean P. Means
The Movie Cricket
review: Pattinson embraces the comic aspects of Mickey’s weird existence, and shows the evolution of Mickey’s heart and spine, even if it takes a few iterations to get it right.
But Mickey 17 doesn’t have Okja’s same level of compassion and humanity, nor is the critique of capitalism and class inequality as acidly rich as it is in Snowpiercer or Parasite.
Cinema is more than just one frame after another; it can serve as a warning of the world to come. Take Bong Joon-ho's "Mickey 17," for example...[Full review in Spanish]
The film works as an entertaining spy thriller set in the corridors of the Vatican, but also as a serene reflection on commitment, power and faith.[Full review in Spanish]

This is a handsomely staged film, peppered with fascinating ritual and detail, populated by a world-class cast, and focused almost entirely on human interaction and moral drama. It is truly sensational stuff.
...benefits from its superb production design and raft of above-average performances...
"A tense thriller with a heart, a brain, and a soul."
Nicholas D'Agosto is probably strongest among the cast here.

reviewer:
Joshua Rothkopf
Time Out
TOP CRITIC
review: Among this cast of unluckies, there is no future Jamie Lee Curtis. But you do take the film home with you -- to all your own toys -- and that's what decent horror is supposed to do.
Though not a great horror film by any means, Final Destination 5 succeeds as a comedic splatter fest solely by sticking to Stephen King's old motto: 'If in doubt, gross 'em out.'
Final Destination 5 benefits from smart 3D, but even in 2D, the set-pieces will satisfy -- presenting some of the most outrageous kill sequences in franchise history.
It's testament to the 2000 original that there's still so much mileage left in the 'death is coming for you' concept 11 years later.
The film is touching as well as funny, and despite a few dud notes, it mostly works very nicely.

reviewer:
Sophie Butcher
Empire Magazine
TOP CRITIC
review: Despite some sweet moments and strong on-screen talent, The Wedding Banquet’s off pacing and limited character development mean it ultimately falls flat.

reviewer:
Laura Venning
Little White Lies
TOP CRITIC
review: Where The Wedding Banquet really shines is in its characters, not only in its two romantic pairings that feel profoundly real, but also in subverting our expectations of its intergenerational relationships.

reviewer:
Jake Wilson
Sydney Morning Herald
TOP CRITIC
review: This is a broader, more straightforward crowd-pleaser than the first Wedding Banquet, which typically for Lee retained a degree of melancholy and reserve. Sometimes the characters are made to spell out their feelings all too bluntly...

reviewer:
Sean P. Means
The Movie Cricket
review: Director Andrew Ahn does something slightly miraculous in “The Wedding Banquet,” by updating And Lee’s now-classic 1993 gay rom-com for our current moment while maintaining and even deepening its romantic spirit.

Blending subtle gags and quiet melancholy, the remake offers a fresh, affecting perspective on the story, peppered with loving homages to the original including an updated twist on the infamous banquet scene, now tailored for the Gen Z'ers.
The Wedding Banquet old and new may take different paths, but they end with the same conclusion: there is indefatigable strength in the chosen family.

reviewer:
Tim Robey
Daily Telegraph (UK)
TOP CRITIC
review: [Fleur Fortuné's] film feels icily disengaged from other people's ideas, pondering them at a remove – as an opportunity for the actors, a costume brief, a means to an end.

reviewer:
Jonathan Romney
Financial Times
TOP CRITIC
review: Written by Mrs & Mr Thomas (aka Nell Garfath-Cox and Dave Thomas), the film starts from a sharply focused premise, before turning increasingly wayward; it ends up feeling like a Black Mirror episode extended long beyond its punchline.
If it had been twenty minutes shorter, the film would be a lot better, but this is still a cracking feature debut by director Fleur Fortune.
Alicia Vikander steals the show in Fleur Fortuné's promising directorial debut.
I applaud the ambition of the film and some of the attempts to shock the audience, but it is not as fully realized to work as a satire, allegory, or indictment despite wanting to be all three.

Small Things Like These is beautifully observed and deftly assembled. It is furious without raising its voice, and heartbreaking without ever resorting to melodrama. This film is an absolute gem, and you'll be happy you saw it.

reviewer:
Andiee Paviour
Nobody's Reading This But Me
review: Director Tim Mielants frames a rural Ireland that is glacial and grey.

reviewer:
Sandra Hall
The Age (Australia)
TOP CRITIC
review: The ending is a little too abrupt for a film put together with such subtlety. Much is left unsaid, but if the script had gone any further, it would have had to embark on a sequel.
… a bleak vision that reveals something glorious and shining ...

The movie knows how patience can be an important virtue in a work like this; it never accelerates its pace for fear of losing the viewer and, thus, it respects the main character´s own pace. [Full review in Portuguese]
There's a quiet but gripping trepidation that lurks beneath the surface.
I was touched in the end, but never got hooked during the narrative process. I wanted to feel more, I guess.
In the end, Heart Eyes ends up being just another rather generic slasher that didn't do nearly enough to stand out from the multitudes just like it.

reviewer:
Jeffrey M. Anderson
Common Sense Media
review: While its overall vibe is fairly familiar, this horror-romcom mashup is still quite clever, with a knowledge of and appreciation for both genres, as well as appealing and/or funny characters.
Ruben reanimates slasher cliches via a charming rom-com jumpstart with Heart Eyes, a genre hybrid that's bloody fun. These eyes, they're dying.
A fun and breezy good time, maniacally twirling at the crossroads of slasher and rom-com.
A reasonably fun, though could-be-better mashup of rom-com and slasher tropes.
